stream_context.summary: Kaze spends most of the session experimenting with visual styles for the Ice-Castle level (Course 13) of “Return to Yoshi’s Island,” repeatedly testing textures, geometry and N64 combiner settings.  Little actual geometry is finalised, but important constraints and ideas are surfaced.  Near the end he abandons art tests to resume off-stream work on a custom replacement for Nintendo’s Libultra OS.

development_findings.summary: Current task is defining the Ice-Castle’s core art style before any real room design; no room is finished yet.
development_findings.quote: “We haven’t even finished one room yet; we’re working on making the art stuff where it looks good before we even try to make the level.”

development_findings.summary: Several stylistic experiments tried: solid ‘frosted’ bricks, environment-mapped spikes, hexagon motifs, deep-blue/bright-white palettes, vertex-alpha snow layers and geometry-node generated icicles.
Technical limitation discovered: can’t use per-vertex alpha if global fog is active, so fog may be sacrificed for better material variety.
development_findings.quote: “We actually removed the fog entirely so we can use the vertex alpha… if you have fog you can’t use vertex alpha.”

development_findings.summary: Transparent ice blocks are effectively off the table because N64 order-of-operations and overdraw become unmanageable.
Performance benchmark: even heavy crystal-spike walls are expected to hold 60 fps, but geometry maintenance/usability for artists is a bigger concern.
development_findings.quote: “The performance doesn’t really… this is still going to be 60 fps, I’m pretty sure.”

development_findings.summary: A new collision system — already implemented elsewhere in the project — is ‘a lot more stable than the vanilla one.’
development_findings.quote: “Yeah, my new collision system is a lot more stable than the vanilla one.”

development_findings.summary: Kaze is writing a new, leaner Nintendo 64 ‘operating system’ (a Libultra replacement) entirely in assembly to free himself from compiler overhead.
development_findings.quote: “I finally figured out how to properly just program in assembly… I’m just gonna write a better [OS].”

development_findings.summary: Composer Badub (referred to as “the dupe”) has already written two tracks, one intended for the Ice Castle and another for a space area.
development_findings.quote: “Fun fact. The dupe made two separate… songs for us.  So this is the song he was thinking for the ice castle.”

context_findings.summary: Kaze’s creative philosophy values emotional impact and is willing to abandon ideas quickly if they don’t ‘feel’ right; he reiterates that art must first evoke feeling before optimisation.
context_findings.quote: “Art is about making you feel emotion.”

context_findings.summary: Humorous but telling anecdote: Zeina ‘makes him celebrate her birthday every day’ and shaved his head when he forgot—showing playful yet intense personal dynamic affecting daily work rhythm.
He expresses disdain for sports like basketball and baseball, using them as comedic interludes to reset focus while testing textures.
Twitch/YouTube income is minimal (~$50/month); main professional income is from his day job at Gears for Breakfast, indicating hobby-driven, not revenue-driven motivation for the hack.
context_findings.quote: “My Twitch… I make like 50 bucks a month.”

biobak.summary: Provides real-time artistic veto power; called an early spike-wall concept ‘unworkable,’ prompting Kaze to drop it and keep searching.
biobak.quote: “If Biobak says this is unworkable… then we can’t just use it.”

badub.summary: Already delivered preliminary Ice Castle and space level music tracks, surprising even Kaze.

zeina.summary: Sends multiple Ice-Castle reference images during stream, steering Kaze toward deep-blue/white high-contrast examples.
Personal dynamic: expects daily ‘birthday’ wishes; playful banter influences stream mood.
zeina.quote: “She got so upset… then she just shaved me again.”

key_stories.title: The Unending Search for an Ice-Castle Style
key_stories.summary: Kaze spends the entire stream iterating through textures, geometry-node experiments and reference images, only to conclude that nothing is yet workable.  Feedback from Biobak and Zeina shapes constant pivots.
key_stories.challenge: Make an Ice-Castle that reads as mysterious, N64-feasible and distinct from a generic ice cave.
key_stories.process: Tested environment maps, vertex-alpha snow overlays, hexagon tiling, spike walls, CI4 bricks, and fogless rendering; consulted Frozen, Adventure Time and community references; live-tweaked combiners and geometry nodes.
key_stories.outcome: No final solution; plan to let Biobak prototype an idea off-stream while Kaze returns to engine work.
key_stories.key_quote: “We are exploring the space of possibilities… we can’t just be like, oh, first thing that looks good, let’s jump on it.”

key_stories.title: A Better Libultra
key_stories.summary: Off-stream Kaze has started writing a drop-in replacement for Nintendo’s Libultra micro-kernel to improve performance and flexibility for the hack.
key_stories.challenge: Original Mario 64 OS and Libultra ‘suck,’ limiting low-level control.
key_stories.process: Reverse-engineering, rewriting critical routines directly in MIPS assembly.
key_stories.outcome: Work in progress; he plans to resume coding after the art block.
key_stories.key_quote: “Basically, the operating system Nintendo wrote for Mario 64 sucked… so I’m just gonna write a better one.”
